metadata.title: Visualising COVID-19 Pandemic Risk through Network Connectedness

abstract.text:  A novel application of network analysis in healthcare  Providing a direct visualisation of the COVID-19 pandemic risk  Visualisation of the pandemic risk through the degree of connectedness  Presenting a general network concept for continuous assessment on pandemic risk Abstract With the domestic and international spread of the COVID-19, much attention has been given to estimating pandemic risk. We propose the use of a novel application of a well-established scientific approach, network analysis, to provide a direct visualisation (the infographics in Figures 1 and 2) of the COVID-19 pandemic risk. By showing visually the degree of connectedness between different regions based on reported confirmed cases of COVID-19, we demonstrate that network analysis provides a relatively simple yet powerful way to estimate the pandemic risk.

body_text.text: With the domestic and international spread of the COVID-19, much attention has been given to estimating pandemic risk. 1, 2 We propose the novel application of a well-established scientific approach, network analysis, [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8] [9] [10] to provide a direct visualisation of the COVID-19 pandemic risk. By showing visually the degree of connectedness between different regions based on data that are readily available (such as reported confirmed cases of COVID- 19) , network analysis offers a relatively simple yet powerful way to estimate the pandemic risk.

Network analysis has been used for many decades to assess connectedness and systemic risk in financial and banking sectors. We also argue that when applying network analysis to a pandemic situation, the degree of connectedness between the regions can help visualise the pandemic risk.

In medical research, network analysis has also been used in studying gene coexpression, disease co-occurrence, and topological dynamics of the spread of infectious disease. 8, [13] [14] [15] Network analysis is relatively easy to execute as it uses data readily accessible, such as publicly available confirmed number of cases in databases. 14 Here, we retrieved the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases in China from late January to March 2020 and constructed plots of confirmed cases for nine time periods (Period 0 to 8) ( Figure 1A ). 17, 18 We also retrieved the number of confirmed cases worldwide (excluding China) for the same time periods and constructed the plots (Figure 2A ). 19 Next, we constructed network graphs based on the correlation of changes in the number of confirmed cases between two geographical areas (e.g. provinces). If the correlation is >0.5, the two areas are connected in a network. Network connectedness provides more timely prediction on pandemic risk than relying on the raw data of daily confirmed cases. In Figure 1B suggesting that the situation in Europe and America was getting worse. There is sign of decrease in connectedness in Period 8 (Mar 19 -Mar 25) ( Figure 2J ) though the number of daily confirmed cases did not soar until Period 8 ( Figure 2A ).

We have demonstrated that, compared to just relying on reported confirmed cases of COVID-19, network analysis can provide a powerful and clearer visualisation of the pandemic risk through the degree of connectedness in pandemic network graphs. Being data-driven and based on data that are readily accessible, network analysis can supplement traditional modelling techniques to enhance estimation of pandemic risk and provide more timely evidence to inform preparedness plans.

Thus, the more frequently the regions are connected, the higher the density of the lines in the network graphs and the stronger the tendency of co-evolution of virus propagation among the regions. And an increase in pandemic risk is suggested (see for example,Figure 2H, the network graph for worldwide excluding China in the second week of March). FIGREF3.text: Jan 20 -29), the number of confirmed cases was low and just began to rise in China. Despite this, the network graph at Period 0 already showed a high connectedness between provinces (Figure 1B), indicating the imminence of an epidemic in China. Further, although the number of daily confirmed cases continued to rise exponentially in China in Period 1 (Jan 30 -Feb 5) (Figure 1A), the network graph (Figure 1C) already showed a significant decrease in connectedness compared with that in Period 0. The decrease in connectedness provided an early sign of an improvement of the epidemic, probably due to the lockdown of Wuhan and another 15 cities to reduce social interaction. Similarly, a slight decrease in daily confirmed cases in China was first recognized in Period 2 (Feb 6 -Feb 12) and Period 3 (Feb 13 -Feb 19) but the trend of decline was not obvious until Period 4 (Feb 20 -Feb 26) (Figure 1A). The network graphs, however, provided a clearer visualisation of the significant decrease in connectedness from Period 1 to period 4 (Figure 1C -F), signaling the trend of decline as early as from Period 1. Also, for the other countries in the same time periods (Period 0 -8) (see , network graphs provided powerful visualisation of the pandemic risk more so than that revealed by the daily confirmed COVID-19 cases. For example, there was a marked increase in connectedness between European, American and other countries in Period 4 (Feb 20 -Feb 26) (Figure 2F), indicating increasing pandemic risk even though the number of daily confirmed cases in Europe was still low in Period 4 (Figure 2A). This phenomenon was similar to that observed in China at Period 0 (Figure 1B).
